conclusion: Conductor rod MN moves horizontally on the smooth guide rail with mass m, length L, and negligible resistance, initially moving leftward.
Magnetic field is uniform and directed vertically downward with magnetic induction B.
Two resistors with resistance R are connected at the ends of the guide rail (AB and CD).
Spring is initially at its natural length and forms a vibration system with the conductor rod MN.
Joule heat generated in the resistor R between AB is Q during the process.

Conductor rod MN moves in the magnetic field, inducing an electromotive force (EMF) due to electromagnetic induction, driving a current through the circuit, which interacts with the magnetic field to produce an Ampere force on the rod.
Initial kinetic energy of the rod is converted into elastic potential energy of the spring, Joule heat Q dissipated in the resistor, and work done against the Ampere force.
EMF induced in the conductor rod is given by \( \mathcal{E} = B \cdot L \cdot v \).
Current I in the circuit is \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} = \frac{B \cdot L \cdot v}{R} \).
Ampere force F acting on the rod is \( F = I \cdot L \cdot B \), leading to \( F = \frac{B^2 \cdot L^2 \cdot v}{R} \).
At the initial moment, the velocity of the rod is \( v_0 \) (initial velocity), thus the initial Ampere force is \( F_{\text{initial}} = \frac{B^2 \cdot L^2 \cdot v_0}{R} \).
Joule heat Q dissipated in the resistor is related to the work done by the Ampere force, \( Q = \text{Work done by Ampere force} = \int F \cdot dx \).
Final answer: The magnitude of the Ampere force on the rod at the initial moment is \( F_{\text{initial}} = \frac{B^2 \cdot L^2 \cdot v_0}{R} \).
